title: Hurricane Dorian has struck the Bahamas, with Florida, Georgia, and the Carolinas in its path. Here is where and when it's due to strike next.
text:
Hurricane Dorian, a Category 3 storm that devastated much of the Bahamas, is slowly churning toward northeastern Florida, Georgia, and the Carolinas.

The National Hurricane Center (NHC) said it would bring "life-threatening storm surge and devastating hurricane-force winds" to Florida. It's expected to be at its nearest, and most threatening, late on Tuesday.

Storm surge warning are in place for sections of the east coast of Florida, but the storm itself may not make landfall at all.

Dorian, producing maximum sustained winds of 120 mph as of 2 a.m. ET on Tuesday, is projected to move north towards South Carolina, nearing the state's east coast late Wednesday.

The potential track is shown above on Google's Crisis Map, which is based on US government data. It suggests that Dorian could rake the US coast without making landfall.

This map shows the official National Hurricane Center's version of the cone:

A map showing the current location, and projected route, of Hurricane Dorian, accurate as of 02:00 a.m. on Tuesday, September 3, 2019. NOAA

NHC forecasters say Dorian's trajectory could change, and has proved difficult to predict this week.

description: Hurricane Dorian's path is nearing Florida, where it is no longer projected to make landfall, but still cause 'devastating hurricane-force winds.'
